name: Triple Berry Oatmeal Muffins
description: These big, moist, and fluffy Triple Berry Oatmeal Muffins are a real treat for breakfast and boast the goodness of rolled oats. Freezer friendly!

recipeInstructions.text: Prepare the oat crumble topping first, so it's ready to go on the muffins as soon as they're mixed. In a small bowl, combine the oats, butter, brown sugar, and cinnamon. Use your hands to massage the oats, brown sugar, and cinnamon, into the butter until it's evenly combined and clumpy. Refrigerate the mixture until you're ready to top the muffins.
recipeInstructions.name: Prepare the oat crumble topping first, so it's ready to go on the muffins as soon as they're mixed. In a small bowl, combine the oats, butter, brown sugar, and cinnamon. Use your hands to massage the oats, brown sugar, and cinnamon, into the butter until it's evenly combined and clumpy. Refrigerate the mixture until you're ready to top the muffins.

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 500ºF. In a large bowl, combine the all-purpose and whole wheat flours, oats, brown sugar, white sugar, salt, baking powder, and cinnamon. Stir well.
recipeInstructions.name: Preheat the oven to 500ºF. In a large bowl, combine the all-purpose and whole wheat flours, oats, brown sugar, white sugar, salt, baking powder, and cinnamon. Stir well.

recipeInstructions.text: In a separate bowl, whisk together the milk, eggs, and oil.
recipeInstructions.name: In a separate bowl, whisk together the milk, eggs, and oil.

recipeInstructions.text: Pour the whisked wet ingredients into the bowl with the dry ingredients. Stir just until they are combined, it doesn't need to be perfectly mixed. There may still be clumps and a few dry spots, but it's important to avoid over mixing.
recipeInstructions.name: Pour the whisked wet ingredients into the bowl with the dry ingredients. Stir just until they are combined, it doesn't need to be perfectly mixed. There may still be clumps and a few dry spots, but it's important to avoid over mixing.

recipeInstructions.text: Add the frozen berries to the mixture and gently fold in. Again, avoid over mixing because the berry juice will turn the muffins blueish grey.
recipeInstructions.name: Add the frozen berries to the mixture and gently fold in. Again, avoid over mixing because the berry juice will turn the muffins blueish grey.

recipeInstructions.text: Line eight muffin tin cups with paper liners, then fill each one to the top with the muffin batter (use more cups if needed, just make sure to fill to the top). Sprinkle the prepared oat crumble topping onto each muffin.
recipeInstructions.name: Line eight muffin tin cups with paper liners, then fill each one to the top with the muffin batter (use more cups if needed, just make sure to fill to the top). Sprinkle the prepared oat crumble topping onto each muffin.

recipeInstructions.text: Transfer the muffin tin to the oven and immediately turn the heat down to 400ºF. Bake for 22-25 minutes, or until the muffins have risen into peaks, have cracked slightly, and are deep golden brown on top. Remove the muffins from the oven and the muffin tin (use a knife to loosen any parts that have spilled out over top) and allow them to cool.
recipeInstructions.name: Transfer the muffin tin to the oven and immediately turn the heat down to 400ºF. Bake for 22-25 minutes, or until the muffins have risen into peaks, have cracked slightly, and are deep golden brown on top. Remove the muffins from the oven and the muffin tin (use a knife to loosen any parts that have spilled out over top) and allow them to cool.

review.reviewBody: I’ve made this recipe several times over the years and it always turns out great. The crumble topping makes them amazing!
Thank you taking time to answer the question. Your right. I guess I’ll go buy a muffin tin.
If I don’t have a muffin tin could this be made into a coffee cake instead? Would the bake time be the same?

To make these vegan friendly, I subbed 1/2 cup apple sauce for the eggs and used oat milk instead of regular milk. They turned out great! I used vegan butter for the crumble, but another commenter suggested coconut oil which I’m sure also works! Thanks for the recipe. Absolutely delicious!

These muffins are amazing! I like that they are not overly sweet, and they are very filling! I live at high altitude (7200 ft) so I reduced the baking powder to 2 1/2 teaspoons and also made it with almond milk, but followed the rest of the recipe to a T and they turned out nice and tall. I didn’t have muffin liners on hand, so just greased the pan and they came out perfect. Thanks for sharing!

I needed to heat my house up this morning and these muffins looked like the perfect ticket. Nice high heat at the beginning! And they turned out great. They are just the right amount of sweet, like a good quality scone, the berries give an extra punch of flavor, and the oatmeal gives good texture. I doubled the cinnamon in the batter just on a hunch, and it seemed like a good move. I also didn't have muffin liners, so I just sprayed the pan good and baked them "naked" and that worked fine. Less garbage anyways. Made exactly 9 muffins full to the brim and I ate 2 right out of the oven with some butter. Mmm.
I forgot to mention that I did not have butter for the oat crumble, so I replaced it with coconut oil instead. It's a good substitute!

Quarantine shopping left me with an enormous can of rolled oats, so I tried this recipe as a way to help use them up.  OMG!  The oats and whole wheat flour give these muffins a very satisfying texture, and the cruncy topping is to die for!  They were a hit with the whole family, and a new addition to the morning lineup for sure.

keywords: bakery style muffins, berry muffins, muffin recipe, oatmeal muffin recipe
